Award.AwardTitle: Homotopical techniques in Geometry and Topology
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this proposal we propose several projects of geometric significance. Among the projects proposed is the study of the stable sympelctic category. This category is the stabilization of A. Weinstein's symplectic category (which is a domain category for geometric quantization). We achieve stabilization by inverting the symplectic manifold given by the complex plane. The resulting stable category is extremely tractable, and retains a lot of structure (like an action of the Grothendieck-Teichmuller group that was conjectured by Kontsevich). Another project proposed is the continuing study of real Johnson-Wilson theories, with collaborator W.S.Wilson. This is a computationally accessible theory that contains higher-level information which can be used to solve several geometric problems like the non-immersion problem. Among other projects proposed include the study of the homotopical and representation theoretic properties of Kac-Moody groups. These groups are of interest in mathematical physics and topology.

The major thrust of the above proposal is to construct and apply (homotopical) techniques and methods designed to better understand hard geometric questions that may be of interest to a wide variety of mathematicians and mathematical-physicists. One such technique is called stabilization, which suitably linearizes a possibly intractable question, thereby making it accessible. The process often allows us to gain a lot of insight into the original problem. Another technique studied is the study via classifying spaces. The classifying space is a construction that takes the set of symmetries of a geometric object, and encodes them into a space that can then be studied in standard ways to recover information about the original geometric object.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proposal sought to apply various new and old techniques in topology to problems that were wide in their scope.

Of particular interest to this project were questions pertaining to Mathematical Physics. One of these questions inquired into the structure of the Symplectic Cateogy. This category encodes the symmetries of Quantum Field theory: the language that describes our physical universe. The technique used is called stabilzation which can be described by inquiring what symmetries remain if the physical system did not care about the number of free (bosonic) particles that it was allowed to include. We were able to completely describe these symmetries in terms of objects called Ring Spectra (which are standard objects used in topology to study arbitrary spaces). In particular, we were able to verify the existance of certain symmetries (after stabilization) that were conjectured to exist by various important mathematicians and physicists. 

Other projects in this proposal were directly related to the objects called spectra mentioned above. In particular, we studied an important spectrum called Johnson Wilson Spectrum which comes endowed with an involution (a symmetry that toggles back and forth). Seen under the light of this symmetry, the Johnson Wilson spectrum encodes much more structure and can consequently be used to study spaces beyong the techniques previously availabe. In particular, we computed the effect of these (invariant) Johnson Wilson spectra on several standard spaces that are traditionally used as building blocks for other spaces.

Among the other projects studied in the proposal was also a project on the nature of symmetries itself. It turns out, that the collection of symmetries in the abstract often have internal structure in themselves. As such, one says that these symmetries form a topological group. In our proposal, we studied a partiular kind of infinite dimensional (or very large) topological gorups known as Kac-Moody groups. These groups are known to play an important role in the symmetries of string theory (or M-theory). One of our results in the proposal allowed us to understand the shape of these groups by decomposing them in terms of small (well-known) symmetry groups known as Lie groups that were then completely undertood and recombined to deduce information about the Kac-Moody group.

All the projects considered in our proposal had an overarching theme: That of developing techniquies in topology with the aim to apply these techniques to varied questions, both withing topology and also outside. We believe that this proposal was highly successful in this task.
